loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more bunches of plantain to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Moyinoluwa

texts.en:
Moyinoluwa is 45 years old and a mother of five. She sells cooked food, before now she sold cooked food from place to place but could sell only what she could carry; after joining LAPO she was able to own a shop.

Moyinoluwa opens her shop every day of the week 8 am to 6 pm except on Sundays. Her biggest priority is feeding the children and making sure their school fees are paid.

Moyinoluwa is asking for a loan of 50,000 Nigerian naira to purchase raw foodstuff in bulk at a reduced rate, which she said will enable her meet the demand of her customers. She says thank you to Kiva lenders and LAPO microfinance.

loans.use: Ingredients for food production

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy used clothes for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase shoes in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase underwear and jewelry

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase wine and drinks to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase groceries and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more stockfish to sell.

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en: Prossy N. G. is a hardworking businesswoman, age 28, and a resident of Kiyunga. She is a married woman blessed with one child and looking after two dependents as well. She owns a retail shop which she has been operating for over six years. She is using the loan to purchase retail items such as cooking oil, books, ground nuts, soap, sugar, and salt to sell in her shop. She also plans to expand her business. Her hope for the future is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase items for her retail shop.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: N. Esther, a hardworking businesswoman of 29 years old, is married with three children, two of whom attend school. She also looks after five dependents. She has owned a spare parts shop for over twelve years. She is using the loan to purchase spare parts, grease, oil lubricants, and so forth to improve on her shop and more so to meet her customers' demands. Her future hopes are to expand her shop and educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts, grease, oil lubricants, etc.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: M. Rose is a 45-year-old married businesswoman blessed with four children, two of whom attend school. She also looks after two dependents. She owns an agrochemical shop which she has been operating for over six years. She is using the loan to purchase shop items such as spades, hoes, axes, fertilizers, and so forth for sale to farmers.

loans.use: To purchase items such as spades, hoes, axes, fertilizers, etc.

loans.name: Sulaiman

texts.en: K. Sulaiman, a 46-year-old hardworking businessman, is married with two children, one of whom attends school . He also has one dependent. He owns a shop selling mattresses, pillows, and so forth. He has been in this business for over eight years. He is using the loan to purchase shop items such as mattresses, pillows, etc. for sale. He is a hardworking businessman whose dream is to expand the business and educate his children.

loans.use: To purchase shop items such as mattresses, pillows, etc.

loans.name: Sylivia

texts.en: K. Sylivia is 30 years old, married and a resident of Mayangayanga Nakifuma. She has no children but she has one dependent going to school. She has owned a retail shop for over eight years. She is using the loan to purchase retail items such as sugar, salt, soap, and so forth to sell. Her future hope is to expand this business.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, salt, soap, and so forth

loans.name: Zuhura

texts.en:
N. Zuhura is a hardworking business woman who is married to Gigulu Peter. They are blessed with six children who are all in school. N. Zuhura is a resident of Kayunga west. 

She has been in her business for over eleven years. She is using the loan to purchase medicine and other clinic items. Her hope is to educate children who wish to become doctors in the future.

loans.use: To purchase medicine and other clinic items.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
W. Stella is thirty-two years old.  She is married with four children who are all in school.

She owns a retail shop and has been operating her business for over eight years. She is using the loan to purchase stock such as sugar, salt, milk, rice, match boxes, biscuits, and so forth for sale. She is a hardworking business woman whose dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase stock such as sugar, salt, milk, rice, match boxes, and biscuits

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret A. is a hard-working business woman who owns a retail shop at Arua Hospital. She is 35 years old, married and blessed with five children, who all attend school.

Margaret A. has been operating her store for almost three years. She plans to use the loan to purchase retail items such as posho (a starchy dish made from corn flour), beans, sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil, pens and biscuits, to resell. Her dream is to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase retail items to resell

loans.name: Asraf

texts.en:
Asraf A. is a hard-working businessman.  He is 33 years old and married with two children.  One child is living with him and in school.

Asraf operates a hardware business and he is also a blacksmith. He has been in this business for 10 years. He will use the loan to purchase more hardware items such as tins, iron sheets, and so forth for his business. He hopes to generate more profits out of his business in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more hardware

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en: Isaac O. is a hard-working businessman.  He is 39 years old and married with six children, who all are attending school.  Isaac has operated a produce business for almost five years. He will use the loan to purchase items such as cassava flour, millet, sorghum, maize and posho (a starchy dish made from corn flour) for sale. Isaac's customers are mostly schools.  He hopes to expand his business in the future.

loans.use: To purchase items such as cassava flour, millet, sorghum and maize to sell

loans.name: Isufu

texts.en: Isufu K. is a 35-year-old hardworking businessman. He is married and has five children and six additional dependents who are all in school. He deals in second-hand clothing and has been operating his business for over 10 years. He is using the loan to purchase stocks of clothes in Kampala, Congo, for sale in West Nile Paidha market. His dream is to obtain a big wholesale shop in Paidha town.

loans.use: To purchase stocks of clothes

loans.name: Alexander

texts.en:
Alexander is married and has one child. He offers taxi services using his personal car. Alexander used to work at a plant which was later downsized. Then he worked as a guard at a security company. After that he decided to become self-employed and began using his car as a taxi. He has been a taxi driver for 6 years now.  His monthly income is about 5,000 UAH.

Alexander would like to borrow 8,000 UAH to fix the engine of his car. His business goal is to make enough income to be able to help his son get a better education. Alexander is a family man and has decided to work only during the day time in order to spend more time with the family.

loans.use: To fix his engine.

loans.name: Jorge Gustavo

texts.es: El señor Jorge Gustavo S. D. cuenta con el negocio de transporte tiene un auto station wagon el cual el mismo lo maneja, eligio este negocio ya que es rentable y viene trabajando con una experiencia de mas de 30 años, tiene un ingreso de s/300 aprox. mensual. El crédito que se le esta otrogando lo utilizará en el mantenimiento de su vehículo. Es casado, su conyuge es cesante del ministerio de educación tienen dos hijos mayores de 34 y 29 años ellos son totalmente independientes ya que tienen familia. El señor Jorge tiene el sueño de comprarse otro auto mas adelante.
texts.en:
S. D. Jorge Gustavo, with identification number DNI 21403043, currently lives in the neighborhood of El Carmen, near Ica. His work is in the field of transportation. He is married and lives in his own house. He is requesting the loan for maintenance work on his car. He hopes to continue expanding his business in the future.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investing in maintenance for his car as a business asset

loans.name: Jefter

texts.en:
Jefter is 51 years old and married with four children, ranging in age from 19 to 26 years old. Only his youngest child is still currently enrolled in school. He has run a mixed farm in western Kenya, near the town of Kitale, for the past ten years. His primary income comes from the sale of beans, vegetables, milk, and timber to the local market and re-sellers. Overall the main challenges to success are transportation of products to market and lack of steady access to markets. 

Jefter requested this loan through Juhudi Kilimo for Kes. 31,200 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that the extra income from this loan will help improve the living standards of his family and allow for better education for his children. In the future, Jefter would like to become a big supplier of milk and he would also like to purchase a posho mill, a machine for grinding maize into flour.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Aoko

texts.en:
Aoko is a farmer near Kitale, Kenya.  She is 32 years old and married with three children, who range in age from 4 to 11 years old. They all attend school. She's been farming for five years and sells maize, milk, and eggs at the local market. She faces a number of challenges, including poor transportation, competition, and high costs to maintain her posho mill (a machine that grinds maize into flour).

Aoko requested this loan through Juhudi Kilimo.  She will use the KES 31,200 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says that the extra income from this loan will improve her life and enable her to meet her family's basic needs. In the future, she would like to be one of the main supplier of milk and eggs in her area. She hopes to purchase another three dairy cows and an additional posho mill to generate further income to support her family.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent is 26 years old and married with two children. They are 1 and 4 years old, with the elder currently enrolled in school. He is a dairy farmer in western Kenya, near the town of Litein, where he has been farming for over two years now. His main source of income comes from selling milk to the Kenyan Cooperative of Cremeries.

Vincent recently completed his first loan with Juhudi Kilimo, and he has now requested this loan of KES 80,000 to purchase a motorbike. He says that the extra income from this loan will help improve his net worth and improve his dairy farming through better transportation. In the future, Vincent would like to acquire another dairy cow and upgrade his dairy housing unit.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Kenya! This is 48-year-old Margaret C. from Kitale, Kenya. She is widowed with six children between the ages of 10 and 22, all of whom are currently attending school.

Margaret runs a farm where she sells milk and eggs at the local market. She has been running this business for five years now, and she earns some additional income from running a small kiosk. 

Margaret has requested a loan of KES 30,000 in order to expand her stock of poultry. The extra income from this loan will help her family by providing meat for consumption and money for school fees for all her children. In the future, she plans to acquire three good dairy animals and to become the main supplier of chickens in her area. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To expand her stock of poultry

loans.name: Lenet

texts.en:
Lenet is 29 years old and married with three children between one and four, with only the oldest currently in school. She's been farming for three years now in western Kenya, near the town of Kitale, and she earns most of her income by selling eggs and hens at the local market. She says that the main challenge to her business is the spread of disease through her poultry stock, combined with the high price of medicines.

Lenet requested this loan through Juhudi Kilimo for Kes. 30,000 to purchase an additional stock of poultry. She says that the extra income from this loan will enable her children to get a good education and improve their quality of life. In the future, Lenet would like to buy two dairy cows and be a supplier of milk to the Kenyan Cremeries Cooperative.

loans.use: To purchase poultry

loans.name: Restaurant 315 Group

texts.en: Salima is leader of the two-person Restaurant 315 Group. She lives in district 11 of Khir Khana, Kabul, Afghanistan. She is 38, married and the mother of five children. She is a good tailor and has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. She is a hard-working woman and happy that the income from her tailoring enables her to support her family. Salima can sew all kinds of clothes and has lots of clients. She needs the loan to purchase sewing materials such as different kinds and colors of thread, needles and so on. She hopes to grow her business and to be able to send her children to better private schools.

loans.use: to expand her business

loans.name: Segundina

texts.en:
Segundina J. is a 70-year-old widow who supports her family by engaging in a general-store business. She lives in Balo Aguisan, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. She has eight adult children between the ages of 24 and 47 years old. Some of them have their own families.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1993. She has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 12,000 PHP.

Segundina is now borrowing 19,500 PHP, so that she can purchase additional capital for her general store. This will be her 20th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 19,500 PHP, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Segundina aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than US$1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe M. is a 52-year-old married woman who supports her family by running an eatery/restaurant. She lives in Sitio Mabuhay, Gil Montilla, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental with her husband, Guilbert, who works as a maintenance carpenter at the City Hall of Sipalay. They have three children who are between 15 and 24 years old.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1994. She has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her eatery/restaurant business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 10,500 PHP.

Fe is now borrowing 20,000 PHP so that she can expand her eatery/restaurant. This will be her 11th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 12,000 PHP, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Fe aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.

They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital for her eatery business

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.en:
Gregoria A. is a 65-year-old married woman who supports her family by manufacturing hollow blocks. She lives in Brgy Cabagahan, Siaton, Negros Oriental with her 71-year-old husband, Grisologo, who owns and raises livestock. They have six children who are all adults.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000. She has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her manufacturing of hollow blocks business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 10,000 PHP.

Gregoria is now borrowing 15,000 PHP, so that she can use the money to purchase additional working capital for her business. This will be her 15th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 15,000 PHP, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Gregoria aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.

loans.use: To purhcase additional working capital

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine L. is a 42 year old, married woman who supports her family through her general store. She lives in Brgy Suba, Bayawan City, Negros Oriental with her husband and their 4 children who are aged between 16 and 23.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2001 and has improved her living conditions with the help of loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 15,000.

Josephine is now borrowing Php 25,000 so that she can expand her general store. This will be her 7th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 25,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Josephine aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and to ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way.

loans.name: Maribeth

texts.en:
Maribeth M. is a 43 year old, married woman who lives in Brgy Suba, Bayawan City, Negros Occidental. She earns a living through her general store.

Maribeth’s husband, Jose Rickman, is a 43 year old seaman.  They have 4 children between the ages of 4 and 21. Three of them currently go to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.

Maribeth joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by running a general store. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 10,000.

Maribeth is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 10,000 was used to fund the operations of her general store, and had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 5th loan of Php 15,000, which she intends to use on her general store. Maribeth is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

loans.name: Rosie

texts.en:
Rosie V. is 56 years old and lives in Brgy Villareal, Bayawan City, Negros Occidental. She earns a living through her general store, eatery and furniture business.

Rosie’s partner, Jessie, is 63 years old and is a consultant.  They have 3 adult children aged between 27 and 33 who are currently working and help their parents with some of the family expenses.

Rosie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by operating her business. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 20,000.

Rosie is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 16,000 was used to fund her business operations and had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 6th loan of Php 20,000 which she intends to use on her general store, eatery and furniture business. Rosie is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

loans.name: Gleceria

texts.en:
Gleceria R. is a 50-year-old woman living in the town of Brgy. Vito, Sagay City.  She is married and has 3 school-aged children.  Gleceria owns & operates a tailoring business, providing general alteration & tailoring services to the local community.  She has been engaged in this business for over 32 years and earns approximately 10,000 Php a month.

In 1993, Gleceria joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities.  She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 19,500 Php from NWTF. She is now requesting a new loan of 19,500 Php which will be used to purchase additional fabrics & materials.  The loan will be the 20th loan taken out by Gleceria from NWTF.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated to pay her children's tuition fees.

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta A. is a 73-year-old woman living in the town of Brgy.Vito, Sagay City. She is widowed and has 10 adult children.  Julieta owns & operates a fishing business, harvesting & selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over 55 years and earns approximately 10,000 Php a month.

In 1992, Julieta joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities.  She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 Php from NWTF. She is now requesting a new loan of 18,000 Php which will be used to purchase fishing equipment such as hooks & nets. The loan will be the 22nd loan taken out by Julieta from NWTF. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to financially support her immediate family members.

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en:
Roselyn S. is a 34-year-old woman living in the town of Purok Ipil-ipil, Brgy. Vito, Sagay City.  She is married and has 4 school-aged children.  Roselyn owns & operates a fishing business, harvesting & selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over 14 years and earns approximately 5,000 Php a month.

In 2005, Roselyn joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities.  She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 19,500 Php from NWTF. She is now requesting a new loan of 19,500 Php which will be used to purchase fishing equipment such as hooks & nets. The loan will be the 9th loan taken out by Roselyn from NWTF. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to pay her children's tuition fees.

loans.name: Juliet's Group

texts.en:
Juliet O. is from the city of Pagadian City. She is 43 years old. Juliet is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Juliet is married and has 5 adult children. Juliet owns & operates a food production/sales business, selling specialty food products in the local community. Juliet has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month.

In 2008, Juliet joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Juliet has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from PMPC. Juliet is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Juliet from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Agustina B's Group

texts.en:
Agustina B B. is from the city of Pagadian City. She is 46 years old. Agustina B is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Agustina B is married and has 4 school-aged children. She owns & operates a general store where she sells a variety of different products. She has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

Agustina B joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Agustina B from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nelly Emerita

texts.es: Nelly Emerita A. J. de 32 años de edad, reside en Ozatlán ubicado en el departamento de Usulután. Vive junto a su esposo quien se dedica a trabajar la tierra en el campo, sembrando y cultivando maíz y otros cultivos. Así mismo vive junto a sus cuatro hijos menores de edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar. Nelly posee una tienda, en la cual comercializa productos de primera necesidad como: leche, embutidos, leche, crema, detergentes y otros productos más los cuales son fundamentales para el hogar. El mayor deseo de ella es el de poder surtir su negocio y de esta manera salir adelante y brindarle todo lo necesario a sus cuatro hijos, y de esta misma forma darle la ayuda necesaria a su esposo para poder tener una mejor economía familiar. Es por esta razón que Nelly solicita un préstamo a Integral, a través del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para realizar este sueño el cual es mejorar las condiciones del negocio y de esta manera la de su familia.
texts.en:
Nelly Emerita A. J. is 32 years old and lives in the town of Ozatlán in the Usulután region. She lives with her husband, who is a farmer who grows corn and other crops. They live with their four minor children who are all in school. Nelly has a shop where she sells milk, cold cuts, sour cream, detergent, and other household necessities. Her greatest desire is to fully stock her shop so she can get ahead financially and provide everything that her four children need. She also wants to be able to help her husband so that their household is more stable financially. For this reason, Nelly is requesting a loan from Integral. She will use the loan to realize her dream of improving her business and in this way improve her family's standard of living.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of staple items

loans.name: Florida's Group

texts.en:
Florida P. is from the village of Del Pilar, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 50 years old. Florida is the group leader of a 13-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Florida is married and has 4 adult children. She owns & operates a general store where she sells food & daily use products. She is just starting this business.

In 2008, Florida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Florida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 


About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Verna Rojas' Group

texts.en:
Verna R. is from the village of Nazareth, Pagadian City. She is 33 years old. Verna is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Verna owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food products in the local community. Verna has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately PHP5000 PHP a month for these activities.

Verna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Verna is requesting a new loan of PHP13000. Verna plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional Income

loans.name: Zenny's Group

texts.en:
Zenny S. is from the village of Upper Bayao, Tukuran ZDS. She is 28 years old. Zenny is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Zenny is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Zenny owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The income for her business comes from planting & harvesting rice for sale. Zenny has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately PHP12,000.00  a month for these activities.

In 2008, Zenny joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Zenny has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000.00 PHP from PMPC. Zenny is requesting a new loan of 14900 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Zenny from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Cecilia's Group

texts.en:
Cecilia P. is from the village of Alindahaw, Tukuran ZDS. She is 46 years old. Cecilia is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Cecilia is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Cecilia owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Cecilia has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 12,000.00 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Cecilia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cecilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000.00 PHP from PMPC. Cecilia is requesting a new loan of 14900 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Cecilia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel S. had started up a small hog fattening business when she joined ASHI in 2009. After four months of fattening, Maricel reinvested her income in the business by buying more piglets. She enjoyed spending her profit towards the needs of her three children, in addition to the income of her loving husband, a security guard. 

Looking beyond her present life, where her children between the ages of two and eight years old, Maricel is worried that once they will be studying in higher level of education, they will be needing a large amount of money for support. With her economic status now, she cannot afford to pay the tuition through to their graduation them from college so that they may have a better career. With that in mind, she wants to grow her hog fattening business. She wants to raise more hogs to sell: more either alive or slaughtered, after four months of raising, for a much larger amount of profit. To be able to accomplish her business desires, and her dreams for her famil,y she is requesting for a much larger amount of loan to ASHI. With the loan she is requesting, she hopes to be able to feel in her heart someday the fulfillment of being a great wife, mother and a businesswoman.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets for fattening.

loans.name: Amin Agha Shir Ali Group

texts.en:
Shir Ali is the group leader of Amin Agha Shir Ali group. He lives in the 11th district of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and is a very responsible man. He has a general store where all kinds of goods are available.

He needs the loan to complete his inventory and to purchase more beverages, food and sanitary products. He would like to expand his business and to be a wonderful business dealer in the future.

loans.use: to purchase goods to complete his inventory

loans.name: Melecia

texts.en:
Despite being poor, Melecia D. is very happy with her life because she has two loving children (aged 9 and 12), and a very supportive husband. Before she became a member of ASHI in 2009, she devoted her time to taking care of her children and attending to the needs of her family. She would make sure that, when her husband came home from working in the rice field all day, a meal was prepared that they would share on their small table. However, there would be times when she had nothing to prepare because her husband, being the sole provider and a hired farm laborer, had a small and sporadic income. Melecia aspired to have her own business and to play an economically productive role as well as raising children. 

In 2009, with the support of her husband, she joined ASHI and requested a loan. She started a hog fattening and a rice retail business. With her business she was able to augment her husband’s income and their lives have now improved a bit. Melecia is now requesting a much larger loan to really grow her business and profits. She wishes to raise more hogs and to sell large volumes of rice from their house. Someday she hopes to have enough business capital to build a store, separate from their house, where she can sell grocery items and rice to increase her income.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets for fattening and increase the volume of rice she sells in her store.

loans.name: Noor Mohammad Qaleen Baf Group

texts.en:
Arozo is a member of Noor Mohammad Qaleen Baf group. She is a young girl of 28, single and lives in a household of 6 members. 
She has a carpet weaving business and is supported in this by two of her sisters. She operates this business in one of the rooms of her house. 


She has lots of clients who really like her work and who purchase most of the carpets that she and her sisters weave. She produces different designs for them. Most of them are small, however, others are large.


She needs the loan to purchase a new carpet frame and to expand her business. She would like to say lots of thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase a carpet frame and expand her business

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Since the beginning of Rowena S.’s membership in ASHI, her determination to grow her ice-cream making/sales business has been strong. Her loan from ASHI is her main source of financial support. The profit from her business provides her family with food and other basic needs because this  is the only income source for both her and her husband. 

Since she started receiving loans from ASHI in 2004, her business has grown and she has been able to support the needs of her four children, particularly their educational needs. Soon, her eldest will go to college and her second child is in secondary school. They will need much financial support until they graduate from college. Therefore, Rowena really wants her business to become stable and to increase the family income while her two youngest children are still in elementary school. She is requesting a much larger loan from ASHI to help finance her aspirations for the business. 

With hope that, someday, she will fully achieve her dream of lifting her family above poverty, Rowena is very enthusiastic about managing her business well, in partnership with her loving husband.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients in bulk for her ice-cream production business.

loans.name: Torpeki Nasima Group

texts.en:
Torpeki is the group leader of Torpeki Nasima group. She lives in the 11th district of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married and lives in a household of 8 members. She runs a tailoring business from her house. She sews all kinds clothes, both small and big sizes. She is well known among her neighbors for her work and they mostly bring their cloth to her to sew.

 
She wants a loan to purchase another machine because, sometimes, she has problems with the old one. She is glad that this kind of process is really effective for those who want to progress.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Rosemayla's Group

texts.en:
Rosemayla O. is from the village of San Carlos, Tukuran ZDS. She is 39 years old. Rosemayla is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Rosemayla is married and has 3 school-aged children. Rosemayla owns & operates a food production/sales business, selling seafood products such as fish and shrimp. Rosemayla has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Rosemayla joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & to provide working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Rosemayla from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena A. is one of the very good members of ASHI who is requesting a loan to realize her dream of buying more goats for fattening and breeding. Through the proceeds of this business, she hopes to augment the income of her husband. He is a hired radio operator who is paid a small amount of money. Furthermore, she wishes to support the education of her four children, aged from 6 to 19, until they graduate from college and have a better career in the future. 

Goats that Magdalena fattens are sold directly to people in different municipalities during market day. Profit from this kind of business is quite good compared to other businesses that Magdalena has tried. That is why she wants this to become more stable and profitable.

loans.use: To purchase more livestock for raising.

loans.name: Eduardo

texts.en:
Eduardo G. is from the village of Brgy.Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Neuva Vizcaya. He is 39 years old. Eduardo is single. Eduardo owns & operates a tricycle transportation service. Eduardo has been engaged in his business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Eduardo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to repair his vehicle in order to offer better service. He is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase a new motorcycle unit. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Eduardo from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase a new motorcycle unit

loans.name: Tahera Sima Group

texts.en:
Pushton is the group leader of Tahera Sima group. She is a resident of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married with 4 children: two sons and two daughters who are school students. She owns a bakery where she bakes bread for all her neighbors. She is quite famous in her neighborhood for her business. 


She needs the loan to purchase flour and firewood to enable her business to grow. She hopes to have a shop, instead of working in her house, and to give her children a better education through her income.

loans.use: to buy flour and firewood for her business

loans.name: Reyaz Group

texts.en:
Reyaz is a member of the Reyaz group. He lives in 15th district of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is single and lives in a household of five members.
 
He is a hard-working boy who has a marble-selling shop. He has been involved in this business for more than 5 years, and he has gained lots of customers. All kinds and designs of marbles are available in his shop. 

He needs the Kiva loan to rent another shop, which is located next to his current shop, and to purchase marbles as well. He hopes to progress his business and to have a bright future through his business income.

loans.use: Purchasing of marbles

loans.name: Dul

texts.en: Mrs. Dul T., 45, lives in the capital of Phnom Penh. She currently stays at home to take care of the kids and help them do their homework. The family's income is contributed by Dul T.’s husband who appears in the photo. He is a construction foreman. He has a few employees to help him provide this service and he earns at least $8 a day. This couple has been married for many years and is blessed with two young children. One grown daughter works in the garment industry. Dul T. has been purchasing a house which is still not finished. It needs to be decorated. Because Dul T. doesn't have money, she decided to look for assistance from Kiva's field partner HKL.

loans.use: To decorate a house.

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
Shirley Menor P., 25, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Ronald P., a car battery stall owner, and they are blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store for quite some time now.

Shirley has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying groceries needed to replenish and maintain stocks in her variety store.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries to replenish and maintain stocks in her variety store.

loans.name: Gerlie

texts.en:
Gerlie C., 39, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Edwin C., a waiter, and they are blessed with five children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her wooden furniture shop for quite some time now.

Gerlie has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her furniture business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 16,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying raw materials needed to continue production of her furniture.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. She also wants to live out her years with her family in peace.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy raw materials needed to continue production of her furniture.

loans.name: Noime

texts.en:
Noime B., 53, is making sure that her family has enough provision for their daily needs. Married to Folro B., a tricycle driver, she is blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own egg stall and doing direct selling of cosmetics for eight years now.

Noime has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her egg-selling and cosmetics direct-selling businesses.

To ensure the success of her business, Noime would like to apply for a PHP 16,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying more quantities of products to be incorporated into her inventory.

Noime dreams that her businesses will continue to be successful. She also prays that her family will continue to be closer to each other and with the Lord.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more eggs and cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida P., 47, is making sure that her family has enough provision for their daily needs. Married to Nestor P., a court stenographer, she is blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been selling ready-to-wear clothing while also maintaining an electronic phone-loading business.

Aida has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business.

To ensure the success of her business, Aida would like to apply for a PHP 11,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying more quantities of materials that will be incorporated to her current product inventory.

Aida dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha B., 51, is making sure that her family has enough provision for their daily needs. Married to Juan B., a farmer, She is blessed with one child. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own vegetable stall for quite some time now.

Edith has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her vegetable business.

To ensure the success of her business, Edith would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying more quantities of products to be incorporated into her inventory.

Edith dreams that her business will continue to grow and be successful.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites M., 43, is making sure that her family has enough provision for their daily needs. Married to Danilo M., a driver, she is blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own preschool and canteen for quite some time now.

Marites has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business.

To ensure the success of her business, Marites would like to apply for a PHP 28,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying equipment needed for the school and groceries for her canteen.

Marites dreams that many more students will be studying in her school this coming school year.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy equipment needed for the school and groceries for her canteen

loans.name: Feiz Bebe Group

texts.en:
Farhed is a member of Feiz Bebe group and lives in the 11th district of Kabul, Afghanistan. He lives in a family of seven members.

Farhed has a general store and all his family members benefit from the income he generates. He needs the loan to progress his business and to complete his inventory.

Farhed would like say that Kiva is an effective process, supporting entrepreneurs all around the world.

loans.use: To complete his inventory

loans.name: Melros

texts.en:
35-year-old Melros F. has been working hard to grow her sari-sari (variety) store and hog-fattening businesses that she started with the loan she received from ASHI at the beginning of her membership in 2008. She tries to save the money sent to her by her husband, who works abroad, while the proceeds of her business are used to support the daily needs of her 13-year-old child, especially her education.

Melros and her daughter are unhappy when her husband has to work abroad just to give them a better kind of life. Melros really wanted to stop him and ask him to stay. However, she had to let him go because she also wants to give their only child a better future.

Despite that, Melros thinks that once her business has grown and she has saved a lot of money to support their need to improve their standard of living, she can convince her husband not to leave the country but to help her in managing her hog-fattening business instead.

With that vision, Melros is requesting a loan from ASHI to be able to purchase more piglets to raise. She will never stop investing in her business until it becomes more stable and profitable which means her hog-fattening business will turn into a large piggery in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets to fatten and sell

loans.name: Josephine's Group

texts.en:
Josephine D. is from the village of Sto. Domingo. She is 45 years old. Josephine is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Josephine D..

Josephine is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Josephine owns & operates a specialized retail store selling snacks in the local community. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Josephine joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Josephine from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Lily's Group

texts.en: Lily R. is from the village of Tawagan Norte, Labangan, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 54 years old and is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Lily is married and has two adult children. She owns and operates a business raising ducks for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over thirty years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month. Lily joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her first from PMPC. Lily plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: In

texts.en:
Mr. In S. is a 33-year-old married man who currently lives with his parents in a medium-sized house located in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. In S. and his wife were not available for the photograph so his mother is pictured instead.

In S. and his wife take care of two school-aged kids. To feed the family and kids, this couple work as garment laborers and have had this job for years.

In S. has been building a new house in order to live independently with his wife and children but the construction has never been completed due to the fact that he doesn’t have enough money. Therefore, In S. is applying for a loan to help him to finish building his new house.

loans.use: To finish building his new house

loans.name: Lilma's Group

texts.en: Lilma B. is from the village of San Carlos, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 49 years old and is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are both collectively responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if they are delinquent or default. Lilma is married and has four adult children. She owns and operates a food stall, selling seafood products such as fish and shrimp in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over eleven years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Lilma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Lilma is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 2nd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Naira

texts.en:
Naira K. is 37 years old and lives in Sevan with her mother and two children. Naira worked as a cook for four years and after that she worked as a shop assistant for three years.

Naira now manages a clothes and shoes business in Sevan fair. She has been engaged in that business for two years and her mother helps her in that engagement. Naira uses the income from her business for her family’s expenses.

Naira asks for a 500,000 AMD loan to buy the spring season’s clothes and shoes for her shop.

loans.use: To buy the spring season's clothes and shoes for her shop

loans.name: Moeuk

texts.en:
Mr. Moeuk M. is 49 years old and is a motorcycle taxi driver. He always provides his service in and around his community, earning $3 each day. Also he goes to buy and pick up smoked-fish for his wife to sell at the market for a profit.

This couple are determined parents who help each other in order to feed two of their kids who are now enrolled in school and dependent on their income.

The family owns a small farmland on which they always cultivate a rice crop when the farming season comes. Moeuk M. is taking out his loan to buy a cow to help plow the field. In the future he will raise the cow to sell its offspring.

loans.use: To buy cow for plowing and for its offspring

loans.name: Long's Group

texts.en:
Three people make up this group loA. and all live in Skul village in Takeo province. Each member will use the loA. for a different purpose.

Mrs. Long A. is the group leader who has been selected by all the members. She is a white wine maker in the local village and her husband is a farmer who owns 1 hectare (2.5 acres) of land on which he cultivates rice to support his family.

Although they try to work hard, they still earn less income thA. needed. Thus, in order to improve their family living conditions, Mrs. Long A. decided to seek a loA. to buy a cow for breeding.

Mrs. Long A. is the mother of three children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory while the others are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Sun

texts.en:
Mrs. S., 30, has been a cloth-sewing worker in the garment industry for years. The job is to generate money to resolve the financial crisis of her family. S. has a life partner in her husband who is 31 years of age and who drives a truck for a small firm. S. has two school-aged kids who are under her care.

S. needs a loan to build a restroom for her family to improve their hygiene. With any remaining cash from the loan she will buy a piece of land to cover the bad conditions surrounding her house.

From the loan, S. and her family will receive health and happiness.

loans.use: To build a restroom and buy a piece of land

loans.name: May Flor's Group

texts.en: May Flor C. is from the village of Camanga, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 26 years old and is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are both collectively responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if they are delinquent or default. May Flor is married and has one infant child. She owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling clothing and shoe products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 11,000 PHP a month. May Flor joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her first from PMPC. May Flor plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Indrani

texts.en:
Indrani P. is a 29-year-old married woman living in Akurassa with her husband and three children ages 13, 9 and 6.

Indrani has an envelope business where she sells envelopes to local customers. She has been doing this business for one year. She is honest and careful in her business and works hard. She cooperates well with others and has a positive mood. She is very enthusiastic.
 
Indrani has asked for a 20,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to expand her envelope business.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To develop her envelope business

loans.name: Kumuduni

texts.en:
Kumuduni W. is a 43-year-old married woman living in Henegama, Akurassa, with her husband and two children aged 18 and 11.

Kumuduni has a grocery shop which she started ten years ago. In her business she works hard and is honest and careful. She cooperates well with others, and has a positive mood.

Kumuduni has asked for a 25,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to expand her business.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To develop her grocery shop

loans.name: Mihibullo

texts.ru: Мираков Михибулло проживает в районе Восе. Возраст, 31 год. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Михибулло занимается торговлей. Имеет магазин, где продает продукты питания. Этим видом бизнеса занимается более 5 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Mihibullo M. lives in the Vose district. He is 31 years old, married and has 5 children. His wife is a homemaker. Mihibullo is involved in retail sales. He has a store, where he sells food products. He has been in this business for over 5 years. Mihibullo is requesting the loan in order to increase product turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing product turnover

loans.name: Bebe Khowani Group

texts.en:
Zarmina is the group leader of Bebe Khowani Group. She lives in Kabul Afghanistan and is the married mother of four children who are all students in school.

Zarmina has a beauty salon where she works and through which she supports both her children and her husband. She has been involved in this business for more than ten years and she is quite experienced.

Zarmina needs the loan to purchase a new suite of furniture and new quality cosmetics for her salon. She hopes to grow her business and to be a better beautician.

loans.use: To purchase a new suite of furniture and new quality cosmetics for her salon

loans.name: Shahlo

texts.ru: Сафарова Шахло проживает в районе Восе. Возраст, 39 лет. Замужем, имеет 4 детей. Муж на зарабатках в России. Сама Шахло предоставляет услугу. Она в основном занимается пошивкой национальных платьев. В этой области более 5 лет. Кредит берет для закупа метериала.
texts.en:
Shahlo S. lives in the Vose district. She is 39 years old, married and has 4 children. Her husband works in Russia. Shahlo provides sewing services. She is primarily involved in sewing national dresses. Shahlo has been in this business for over 5 years. She is requesting the loan for the purchase of fabric.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fabric

loans.name: Kaluarachchige

texts.en:
A. is a 52-year-old married woman living with her husband and five children aged from eighteen to thirty. She is living in the town of Akurassa, Sri Lanka.

A. has a business that consists of preparing and selling food. She got started doing this business after attending school. She is educated and a wise business lady. She is able to demonstrate strong leadership in group settings. She does her job on time and is very honest.

A. is seeking a 20,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to expand her business.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To develop her food preparation business

loans.name: Ramani

texts.en:
Ramani is a 31-year-old married woman living with her husband. She has one 6-year-old child. Her husband assists with her business and they are very close and work well together.

Ramani has a clothing shop where she sews dresses for local customers and villagers. Two years ago, she started this business.

Ramani has requested a 15,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to expand her sewing shop to help her business. She is grateful for BRAC Sri Lanka because of the support it provides to her.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To develop her clothing business

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married with a teenage son. She is an entrepreneur from Beregovo where she sells children’s clothing merchandise in the local market called “Image”.

Irina is very customer-friendly and polite with all of her clients. She has been in this business for six years. Currently, Irina has 22,000 Grivnyas in inventory and her profit amounts to 8,000 Grivnyas a month.

Irina is requesting a 3,500 Grivnya loan to purchase additional merchandise. Her business is constantly growing and she can hardly handle the high demand she’s facing now. She realizes that lending services are very helpful to her business, as loans allow her to increase her turnover capital and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Hji Hashim Group

texts.en: M. Hashim, who lives in Kabul Afghanistan with his seven-member family, is the group leader of Hji Hashim group. M. is a tinsmith who has operated a shop for the past 15 years, working seven days a week to support his family. Very experienced in this business, he has a large customer base which ensures a satisfactory income each month.  M. is now requesting a loan to purchase the materials essential for his business to continue to progress well.  He would like to thank all lenders around the world for their support.

loans.use: To purchase materials for his shop

loans.name: Olexander

texts.en:
Olexander, who is the married father of three daughters, is a small businessman from the region of Vinogradovo, Kherson where he owns several greenhouses and grows early spring vegetables including cabbage, tomatoes, peppers, sunflowers and watermelons. He has been in this business for 10 years and presently has about 100,000 Grivnyas invested in this farming business.

Olexander is seeking a loan of 15,000 Grivnyas to purchase seeds, fertilizers and a drip irrigation unit for his greenhouses. He believes better quality equipment will facilitate vegetable growth and guarantee richer harvests and better sales as a result. An experienced farmer and agronomist, he loves working with plants and agricultural produce. Olexander hopes to continue expanding his business, building new greenhouses and growing more vegetables and melons for sale in the markets of his region.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and a drip irrigation unit

loans.name: Thanuja

texts.en:
Thanuja M. is a 40-year-old married woman living in Balapatha, Akurassa, in southern Sri Lanka, with her husband and two children aged 16 and 10.

Thanuja has a tailoring shop, a business that she started five months ago. She works hard and greatly enjoys her work. She is very enthusiastic about her business.
 
Thanuja has asked for a 20,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to expand her business.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To purchase items for her tailoring shop

loans.name: Chandrawathi

texts.en:
Chandrawathi is a 57-year-old married woman living in Akurassa in southern Sri Lanka with her husband. They do not have any children.

Chandrawathi has several lots of land that contain paddy farms (flooded parcels of arable land used for growing rice and other semi-aquatic crops), which she first began cultivating ten years ago. In her business she works hard and enjoys it. She is honest and very enthusiastic about her business.
 
Chandrawathi has asked for a 20,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to expand her business.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To develop her paddy farm

loans.name: Margarit

texts.en:
Margarit A. lives in Sevan with her husband who is a pensioner. She has 3 children and all of them are married and live separately from their parents.

Margarit is a food technologist; she worked as a head of a laboratory for a bread-baking plant. After that, she worked as a food technology and culinary teacher at Sevan College. Margarit now manages her own clothes trading business in Sevan fair. 

Mаrgarit is a 5th cycle borrower from Nor Horizon, and now she needs an 800,000 AMD loan to buy an assortment of spring clothes  for her business. In the future, Margarit and her husband intend to become involve in bee-keeping, which will help them to increase their income.

loans.use: To buy an assortment of spring clothes for her business.

loans.name: Nilukshi

texts.en:
Nilukshi is a 26-year-old married woman living in Panadagama, Akurassa, with her husband and one child.

Nilukshi has a business selling grocery items and her husband is also a partner in her business. They started this business in 2008. When her husband goes to buy grocery items for the shop, she works at the shop.

Nilukshi has asked for a 30,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to further develop her grocery business.

Nilukshi is honest and careful in the business. She hopes to provide a nutritious diet to her family through the additional income from her business.

loans.use: To develop her grocery business

loans.name: Adolphus

texts.en:
Adolphus D. is a high school graduate who sells new mobile phones and prepaid phone cards. He sells from a small stand on a street in busy downtown Monrovia, Liberia's capital. With the 71,000 Liberian dollars from this individual loan from Kiva field partner LEAP, Adolphus plans to buy more unlocked GSM mobile phones to resell.

Adoplhus says he's had the business for three years now, and that business is fairly good, except towards the end of each month when potential customers run low on funds as they await payday.  He buys his phones from a Nigerian wholesaler, and says that one day he'd like to be able to import phones from China himself and sell them wholesale.

Adolphus is 32 years old and married. He has two sons, aged 3 and 10. His older son is in the 4th grade. Adolphus also helps to care for his sister.


About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To buy mobile phones and prepaid mobile phone cards for resale.

loans.name: Maria Leonor

texts.es: LA SRA. LEONOR ESTA CASADA, ELLA Y SU ESPOSO EL SR. JUSTINIANO, SON PROFESORES DE ARTES PLÁSTICAS. ELLOS TIENE DOS HIJOS JOVENES QUE ESTAN ESTUDIANDO EN COLEGIO.
