Mrs. S., 53, is a farmer who grows rice in the village, in Phnom Penh City. She has been growing rice since 2000. She is married and lives with her husband and five children. One is a garment laborer. Another daughter is a hairdresser and helps provide support for this loan repayment. Her husband is assisting her at the farming activity.

S. sees that her daughter's hairdressing business is very profitable, thus she hopes to enlarge this business. Because S. doesn’t have money, she is looking to assist her daughter in the improvement of her salon shop and to purchase more salon equipment for her services.

loans.use: To purchase more salon equipment for her daughter's salon shop

loans.name: Kaisho

texts.en:
A. Ruzibiza Kaisho started his banana-selling business thirty-seven years ago in Ntungamo district in western Uganda. With this as his only source of livelihood, he has painstakingly managed to make ends meet, albeit with some long drawn-out seasonal income fluctuations and high labour cost challenges.

With a hard-work ethic in tow, this 57-year-old married and happy-go-lucky father of six has, by and large, kept his business on a consolidated growth course. Kaisho reveals he makes, in a month, close to 480,000 shillings.

Kaisho’s business, in gaining ground over these years, has in effect also meant that his children have been benefactors, especially in their education. His business plan of action for the future is to be able to sell more bananas to an increasingly expanding market. With this loan, he envisages easy progress in achieving his dream.

loans.use: To enhance and expand his banana plantation

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha D. is very happy to have been a member of ASHI in 2009. With the opportunity to receive loan, she has been able to perform her productive role and has become a businesswoman. She has a small backyard poultry business and sells fish her husband catches from the ocean near their house.

Though her business may not be as big as she expects, nevertheless she and her family enjoy its profits being spent for their primary needs. Editha is also excited to support growing her husband’s fishing business using the loan she requests through ASHI. Before, she had almost lost hope because her family revenue is just enough to support the education of her two children in college.

Now that her youngest 24-year-old daughter has been employed as a teacher, the loan she is requesting will surely be used for her business alone, because her daughter and her daughter's husband earn enough to support their other needs at home. Despite Editha’s child supporting her financially, Editha wants to have her own stable source of income so her daughter can enjoy her own life spending her own income.

loans.use: To purchase fishing gear

loans.name: Pim

texts.en:
Mrs. Pim R. is a 42-year-old farmer who has been farming since 1999, earning about $2 per day. Her husband, Mr. Chorn Choun, is 47 years old and a farmer. Pim R. has five teenage children. Two of them are employed in the garment industry and the others are going to school.

Because of increasing transportation costs, Pim R. decided to request a loan of $600 to add to her savings to purchase a motorcycle. This will be used by the family to reduce transportation costs. The loan will improve her business and sustain her family's living.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle.

loans.name: Lan

texts.en:
Lan T. V. is 63 years old. She lives in Yen Phong, Bac Ninh. She has two children, both of whom are married. She is a farmer and has livestock. She also makes and sells imitation paper clothes, which are used as offerings for deceased ancestors. (In Vietnam, many homes have a small altar which is used for offerings to ancestors, including paper replicas of clothes, which are burnt so that the spirits of the gifts can ascend to heaven for the ancestors to use.) 

She has a monthly income of about 3.000.000 Vietnamese Dong. She joined SEDA in 2008 and has repaid punctually. For her next loan, she would like to borrow 8.288.000 VND to buy food for her pigs and paper.

loans.use: To buy food for pigs and to buy paper

loans.name: Phy

texts.en: Mrs. Phy Y. is a widow who lives in a rural area of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. She earns about $2.50 per day from her rice-farming business. Phy Y. has five children, so she has heavy responsibilities. Two of her children help by doing sewing work in a clothing factory but they find it hard traveling to work because they don't have a vehicle. Because of this problem, Phy Y. is requesting a loan to buy a used motorcycle which will enable her children to commute to their work.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more drinks and groceries to sell.

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Mrs. Meas N. is 52 years old and has owned a plot of farm land since 1999. There she grows all types of crops, which she plants twice a year. Meas N. is a good mother of four children, one of whom lives with her and the other three are married and have already started new homes. All four of her children are employed in different jobs. Meas N. is married to Mr. Oeun, 57, who assists her on the farm. Meas N. has been planning to buy a vehicle for the family’s traveling needs, but she does not have enough money to buy one. She is applying for a loan to purchase a new motorbike to provide transportation for her family.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en: When Angelita M. joined ASHI for her first loan, her husband was a partner in managing and growing a “sari-sari” (variety) store and food-vending business. Unfortunately, her husband died in 2007 leaving Angelita with the huge responsibility of supporting their five children— especially the education of her three youngest children in college. Instead of looking on the dark side of life without a husband to support her emotionally and physically, Angelita focused on the things that could help her grow her business and increase its profit. Eventually, thanks to several loans, life for Angelita and her children has been improving. Two of her eldest children have jobs and her business has grown further. Angelita now wants a loan from ASHI to grow her business until it becomes a stable source of income and she can graduate her three children from college to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for her store.

loans.name: Thom

texts.en: Thom T. C., born in 1968, lives in An Ninh, a village in Yen Phong, Bac Ninh with her husband and three children. Thom is a farmer who raises livestock, and she also makes and sells noodles. In 2008, she joined  SEDA to gain access to financial resources, and has always repaid punctually. Thom would now like to borrow 8.288.000 VND (450 USD) to buy more rice to make noodles and invest in her livestock.

loans.use: To buy more rice to make noodles and invest in her livestock.

loans.name: Man

texts.en: Man T. L. is thirty-six years old. She lives in An Ninh village, Yen Phong, Bac Ninh. She is married with two children. She is a seamstress and she sells clothes in the market. She has done this job for 10 years. She has a monthly income of about 4.000.000 VND. She joined SEDA in 2008 and has always repaid punctually. Last time, she borrowed 4.704.000 VND. This time, she would like to borrow 8.288.000 VND more (or 450 USD) to invest in her business, in order to buy new clothing inventory to sell.

loans.use: To buy new clothing inventory to sell

loans.name: Tam

texts.en: Tam T. D., a 42-year-old married mother of three children, has sold fruit in the market for the past 10 years, earning a monthly income of about 3.000.000 VND. A member of SEDA for two years, Tam has repaid her loans punctually. She would now like to borrow 8.288.000 VND more (450 USD) to invest in her business.

loans.use: To invest in her business.

loans.name: Phuong

texts.en: Phuong T. V., 36 years old, lives in An Ninh village, Yen Phong, Bac Ninh, where she is a married mother of three children and operates a store with her husband selling building materials out of her home. They have a monthly income of about 5.000.000 VND.  A member of  SEDA for two years, Phuong would like to borrow 8.288.000 VND (450 USD) to invest in her store. Hopefully, that plan will result in additional profit so her family can afford to buy more household appliances.

loans.use: To invest in her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Buddhika

texts.en:
Buddhika is a 21-year-old married woman living with her husband.  They do not have any children. They are living in the town of Akurassa, Sri Lanka. Her husband is providing her with good help.  

She has a business that consists of making and selling fish tanks. After attending school, she got started doing this business.  She is a young educated woman. She can demonstrate strong leadership in group settings and is a good team worker.  She does her jobs on time and is very honest. 

Buddhika is seeking a 20,000-LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to expand her business.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To develop the fish tank business

loans.name: Munhtsetseg

texts.en:
Munhtsetseg, 37 years old, lives with her child, mother and sibling in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent, in Govi-Altay Province, Mongolia. Munhtsetseg operates a clothing and consumer goods trading business in her town, selling a variety of men's and women's clothes as well as consumer goods at a local market called Shine-Altai. She started her business in 2000, at a rental counter with working capital of 250,000 tugrugs (~ 185 USD); today, however, as a result of a great deal of hard work and determination and help from her sibling, her working capital exceeds 2,500,000 tugrugs (~ 1830 USD). Munhtsetseg purchases the products and with her sibling sells them through two sales channels at the local market.

Munhtsetseg, an experienced trader who has many plans for the future, says, "I would like to expand my business and purchase my own shipping container for my business." She is now requesting a 2,300,000 tugrug (~ 1685 USD) loan to purchase a large amount of inventory including clothing and consumer goods because demand for her products is increasing.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Dhedé

texts.fr:
Madame Dhedé Traoré est une femme mariée de 25 ans et mère de 2 enfants qui vit avec son mari et ses enfants dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Ayant abandonnée l’école en classe de 9ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien), elle s’intéressa très tôt aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment à l’achat vente des pagnes,  des chaussures, des draps de lit, etc depuis maintenant 6 ans. Elle est très sollicitée et appréciée à Bougouni et jouit d’une grande clientèle.
Dans le souci de satisfaire  cette  clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse et exigeante, elle décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso avec qui, elle est à son 6ème prêt individuel après avoir correctement remboursés tous les cinq prêts précédents.
Elle compte utiliser ce nouveau prêt pour acheter, des pièces de  pagnes et des paires chaussures  à Lomé et au Burkina Faso. Elle effectue sa vente à la maison et au grand marché de Bougouni, en détail, au comptant et à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  avec ce prêt, un bénéfice mensuel de 75.000 FCFA qui servira à agrandir son entreprise et d’appui à son mari pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
Mrs. Dhedé Traoré is a married woman, 25 years of age and the mother of two children. She lives wit her husband and children in the North Hérémakono district of the town of Bougoni, in the third administrative region of Mali. Having dropped out of school while in the 9th grade (in the national secondary education system), she very early got engaged in commercial activities, particularly purchasing and reselling “pagnes” (traditional fabric for wrap clothing), shoes, bed linens and so on, which she has been doing for six years now. Her business is very popular and well known in Bougoni, and she has a large number of customers. In order to satisfy the needs of this growing and ever more demanding customer base, she has decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso and is now seeking her sixth individual loan after having properly reimbursed each of the preceding five loans. She plans to use this new loan to purchase “pagnes” and shoes in Lomé and in Burkina Faso. She sells from her home as well at the big market in Bougoni, retail, for cash or on credit. With this loan she plans to achieve a monthly income of 75,000 West African Francs, which will allow her to grow her business and help her husband provide for the family.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing various articles (for resale)

loans.name: Priyangani

texts.en:
Priyangani Vithanage is a 39-year-old married woman living in Nimalawa Akurassa with her two children and husband.  

She has a bicycle repair garage, a business she has been doing for 15 years now, running it independently. In her shop, she fixes and rebuilds bicycles for her local customers.  She devotes her full effort towards her business, growing it step by step, and uses the income to help support herself and her family.  

Priyangani has asked for a 20,000-LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to expand her bicycle garage.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To develop her bicycle repair business

loans.name: Djiguissèmè Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Djiguissèmè sont toutes mariées, majoritairement dans des familles monogames, avec en moyenne 30 an, 3 enfants et habitant toutes à Bènèbougou, un village de la commune de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage, de voisinage, de leurs activités commerciales et d’appartenance à une même association traditionnelle d’entraide des femmes du village de Bènèbougou à l’occasion des travaux champêtres et des évènements sociaux (mariage, baptême, circoncision et funérailles). 
Le groupe Djiguissèmè qui est à son 4ème   prêt solidaire  avec Soro Yiriwaso, après avoir correctement remboursés, les trois précédents font entre autres, l’achat vente de céréales, leurs transformations, la  restauration et le commerce d’articles divers.  
Madame Fatoumata D., dans le souci de diversifier ses activités commerciales décida de faire l’étalagiste depuis maintenant 4 ans.  
Elle utilisera son montant pour acheter : 25 kg de sucre, 4 sachets de (10 petits paquets chacun) de différentes variétés de thés, 1 paquet de lipton, 6 paquets de bonbons, 2cartons de savon de lessive, 10 paquets de bleu et une dizaine de paquet de lames. 
Elle achète ses produits à la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou et effectue ses ventes  à domicile au  comptant  et rarement à crédit à une clientèle mixte hommes, femmes et enfants.
Fatoumata espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 16500FCFA qui servira au remboursement de son prêt, à la contribution à certaines dépenses familiales et à la participation aux évènements (mariages, baptêmes et funérailles). 
Son ambition est de pérenniser son petit commerce afin d’être la 1ère femme  à ouvrir une boutique dans son village tout en préservant ses relations avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The four women of the group Djiguissèmè are all married, mostly in monogamous families, and average 30 years of age and three children each.  They all live in Bènèbougou, a village of the community of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women know one another through ties of kinship, marriage, community, commercial activities, belonging to the same women's traditional mutual-assistance association of the village of Bènèbougou, during farm work efforts, and at societal events (marriages, baptisms, circumcisions, and funerals). The group members are on their fourth solidarity loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso after having correctly repaid all three previous ones.  Their work includes buying and selling grains and processing them, food catering, and commerce in a variety of goods. Ms. Fatoumata D., concerned about diversifying her commercial activities decided four year ago to working on displaying merchandise.  She will use the loan for buying:  25 kg of sugar, four pouches (10 small packets each) of tea of various kinds, a packet of Lipton, six packets of candy, two boxes of laundry soap, ten packets of bleu, and a dozen packets of razor blades.  She buys her supplies at the weekly Ségou fair and sells out of her home, cash accepted but rarely credit, from a customer base composed of men, women, and children. Fatoumata hopes to make a monthly profit of 16,500 francs CFA that will be used to repay the loan, to help cover certain family expenses, and to take part in events (marriages, baptisms, and funerals).  Her ambition is to ensure that her small business continues in order to be the first woman to open a store in her village while preserving her association with Soro Yiriwaso.    

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various store goods

loans.name: Nyamtsetseg

texts.en:
Nyamtsetseg, 27 years old, lives with her husband and son in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent, in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband, Nyamdelger, is a solderer in a private factory and after work operates a taxi service business and helps with his wife's business.

Currently, Nyamtsetseg operates a shoe trading business at Har Horin, one of the biggest markets in Mongolia. She started selling shoes at her mother's counter at the Har Horin market, and since 2006 has independently operated her own shoe trading business. Over the years, she has steadily expanded her business and today her working capital is 2,000,000 tugrugs (~ 1410 USD).

Nyamtsetseg is an experienced trader and enthusiastic person who has many plans for the future. She says, "I would like to expand my business and to sell all types of clothing." She is requesting a 1,700,000 tugrug (~ 1245 USD) loan to purchase summer shoes for her business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Djiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Djiguiya est composé de six membres : 3 veuves et 3 mariées dans des familles polygames avec une moyenne d’âge de 57 ans et 6 enfants. Elles habitent  toutes  Bagadadji, un quartier populaire de la ville de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de voisinage, de leurs activités commerciales au marché de Ségou Coura  et d’appartenance à une même association traditionnelle d’entraide des femmes de Bagadadji. 
Les membres du groupe Djiguiya font essentiellement l’achat vente du riz, de l’atiéké et des condiments alimentaires.
Dans le souci  d’augmenter le volume de leurs activités commerciales les femmes du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur 10ème  prêt  solidaire après avoir correctement remboursés les neuf précédents.
Madame Mariam Koné qui est un des membres du groupe fait l’achat vente de  céréales il y a une vingtaine d’année mais depuis 2005, elle excelle dans la commercialisation du riz. 
Elle s’approvisionne  à la place de Niono sise à Ségou et compte utiliser son prêt   pour acheter une tonne et demi de riz auprès des grossistes. Elle vend en détail et en demi gros à domicile et au marché de Ségou Coura à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Madame compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 43000FCFA qui sera utilisé au remboursement du prêt, à la prise en charge de certains petits besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
The group Djiguiya is composed of six women:  three widowed and three married, in polygamous families.  The women average 57 years of age and six children each.  They all live in Bagadadji, a working-class district of Segou City (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They know one another through ties of marriage, community, commercial work at the Segou Coura market, and belonging to the same women's traditional mutual-assistance association of Bagadadji.  The group members essentially buy and sell rice, atiéké (a cassava couscous), and condiments.  Concerned about increasing the volume of their businesses, the women of the group decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their tenth solidarity loan after having properly repaid the nine preceding ones.  Ms. Mariam Koné is one of the group members, and she has been buying and selling grains for about twenty years.  But since 2005, she has excelled at selling rice.  She gets her supplies at Niono square located in Segou.  She plans on using her loan for buying a tonne and a half of rice from wholesalers.  She sells retail and wholesale out of her home and at the Segou Coura market.  Her customer base is composed of men and women.   Mariam plans on making a monthly profit of 43,000 francs CFA that will be used to repay the loan and to meet certain sundry needs of the family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying rice

loans.name: Renuka

texts.en:
Renuka is a 36-year-old married woman living in Illuppalla, Akurassa in southern Sri Lanka with her husband and child. 

Renuka has been managing her business, which consists of cultivating tea.  She devotes her full effort towards cultivating her tea plants, and uses the income to help support herself and her family.  Her husband also provides her with good help.  

She has managed her tea cultivation for ten years. She works hard in her business, and enjoys good land upon which to grow her tea.  

Renuka has asked for a 20,000-LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to expand the land for cultivation and to purchase chemicals for her tea plants. 

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To purchase chemicals for her tea plants and expand her plot of land

loans.name: Femmes Commerçantes N°18 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement  Femmes Commerçantes (F.C) comme son nom l’indique est un réseau de femmes qui s’activent  dans le commerce.  Il est basé à Grand Thiès et il a été créé depuis 1992 par Madame Maty Niakh l’actuel président du réseau. Cette présidente a eu cette idée  à l’issue d’une formation qu’elle avait bénéficiée  de l’ONG OXFAM à Thiès. Elle connait, ainsi, bien la gestion de groupe, entreprenariat …etc.  Les membres du réseau sont extrêmement dévoués et se rencontrent une fois par mois. Ainsi, après des frais d’adhésion au groupement, chaque membre est tenu de cotiser mensuellement 200 FCFA pour une caisse de solidarité.
Souhaitant se financer, elles décidèrent  d’adhérer à  U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que,  leur réseau se voit scinder en 19 sous groupes de 5 personnes  pour un meilleur profit des financements. Elles sollicitent pour une deuxième fois un prêt de 100 000 FCFA par membre,  soit 500 000 FCFA par sous groupe afin de développer leurs diverses activités.
Cependant, les règlements sont versés à la présidente assistée par la trésorière du groupe, Madame Coumba Seck, pendant leurs réunions mensuelles et ces deux se chargent à leur tour de rembourser U-IMCEC. Ce réseau qui, dit la présidente, n’a qu’un seul et noble objectif : combattre la pauvreté dans les ménages. Actuellement, le réseau compte 19 sous groupes avec chacun une présidente et une trésorière.
Quant au sous groupe Femmes Commerçantes N°18, Madame Vénise T. est la présidente. C’est une femme mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Elle commerce des tissus et du savon venant de la Côte d’Ivoire. Elle compte, cependant avec sa part du prêt, s’approvisionner en marchandises à Rosso en Mauritanie. Les autres membres de ce sous groupe sont Madame Bineta Kassé la trésorière vendeuse d’habits et chaussures, Madame Sabou M. élève coiffeuse et vendeuse de greffages, Madame Aïssatou Lame N. commerçante de produits cosmétiques et Madame Anta D. qui vend des légumes.
texts.en:
The group “Femmes Commerçantes” (F.C.), as its name indicates, is a network of women who are active in commerce. It is based in Grand Thiès and was founded in 1992 by Ms. Maty Niakh, the network’s current president. She got the idea of forming the network after participating in a training session run by the NGO OXFAM in Thiès. She is therefore quite knowledgeable about group management, entrepreneurship, etc. The network members are extremely devoted and meet once a month.  Beyond a membership fee, each member must pay 200 francs CFA monthly into a solidarity fund. Desiring financing, they decided to join U-IMCEC. This is why their network was split into nineteen sub-groups of five persons each to ensure a better profit outcome. For the second time, they are requesting a loan of 100,000 francs per member, that is 500,000 francs per sub-group, to develop their various businesses. However, payments are made at the monthly meetings to the group president, assisted by the group treasurer, Ms. Coumba Seck, who are then responsible for reimbursing U-IMCEC. In the words of its president, the network has only one single, noble objective: to fight family poverty. The network currently numbers nineteen sub-groups, each with its own president and treasurer. As for the sub-group Femmes Commerçantes N°18, the president is Ms. Vénise T.. She is a married woman and the mother of two children. She sells fabrics and soap from Cote d'Ivoire. With her share of the loan, she plans on stocking up on merchandise from Rosso in Mauritania. The other members of this sub-group are Ms. Bineta Kassé, the treasurer and a vendor of clothing and shoes; Ms. Sabou M., a student hair stylist and vendor of hair weaves; Ms. Aïssatou Lame N., a merchant of cosmetics; and Ms. Anta D., who sells vegetables.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies of merchandise

loans.name: Batbayar

texts.en:
Batbayar is 50 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Gobi-Altai province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic tent home, in a small yard that they rent. His daughter is 18 years old and attends university and his wife works as an attendant in a local trading center. 

Batbayar currently operates a billiards center in his town. He has been operating his business since 2005, after gaining experience working at his brother-in-law's billiards center. He started his own business with 10 billiard tables and now has 14 tables. 

Batbayar has been making plans to expand his business and to improve his workplace in the near future. Batbayar is a very hardworking man and his family and his business are very important to him. He says, "I am now saving money for my oldest son's wedding in August." 

He is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug loan to purchase necessary equipment for his billiards center and to improve his workplace in order to attract more customers.

loans.use: To purchase equipment

loans.name: Yankadi Group

texts.fr:
Yankadi est un regroupement de 10 femmes, une veuves et neuf mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans, 4 enfants et habitent  toutes  à Bènèbougou,  un village de la commune de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage, de voisinage, de leurs activités commerciales et d’appartenance à une même association traditionnelle d’entraide des femmes du village de Bènèbougou à l’occasion des travaux champêtres et des évènements sociaux. 
Le groupe Yankadi qui, est à son 5ème  prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursés les quatre précédents, fait l’achat vente de céréales, leurs transformations en couscous, du lait frais et des condiments alimentaires. 
Madame Sitan Dembélé est un membre du groupe  très reconnue dans la transformation de petit mil en couscous qu’elle pratique depuis 30 ans. Elle jouit d’une grande expérience et d’une grande réputation en la matière.  
Pour faire le couscous, le mil est pilé, débarrassé du son, bien lavé, dépourvu de graines de sable puis réduit en farine. Cette farine tamisée est légèrement aspergée avec de l’eau salée, malaxée, tamisée, ensuite  cuite à la vapeur à l’aide d’une marmite percée jusqu’à obtenir du couscous qui sera asséché avant la vente. 
Sitan Dembélé compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 15 sacs de mil sur place auprès des producteurs et vend  au comptant et à crédit à domicile, aux foires hebdomadaires de Banankoro et de Ségou. Sa clientèle est constituée d’hommes surtout des bergers et des femmes. 
Sitan compte réaliser, un bénéfice mensuel de 24000FCFA qui sera utilisé au remboursement du prêt,  à la constitution de fonds de commerce et à la participation aux évènements.
texts.en:
Yankadi is an association of ten women:  one widowed and nine married, mostly in large traditional families.  The women average 39 years of age and four children each, all living in Bènèbougou, a village of the community of Segou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They know one another through ties of kinship, marriage, community, commercial work, membership in the same women's traditional mutual-assistance association of Bènèbougou, while doing farm work, and at societal events.  The group members are on their fifth solidarity loan after having properly repaid the four preceding ones.  They buy and sell grains (and process them into couscous), fresh milk, and condiments. Ms. Sitan Dembélé is a group member who is well-recognized for processing pearl millet into couscous, something she has been practicing for thirty years.  She enjoys a wealth of experience and a great reputation in it. To make this couscous, the millet is pounded, freed of its bran, washed well, cleaned of sand, and then reduced to flour.  The sifted flour is lightly sprinkled with salt water, kneaded, sieved, and then steamed in a perforated vessel until the couscous is obtained.  It is dried and then sold.   Sitan Dembélé plans on using her loan to buy fifteen sacks of millet locally from producers.  She makes her sales, cash or credit accepted, out of her home and at the weekly fairs of Banankoro and Ségou.  Her customer base is composed of men, especially shepherds, and women.  Sitan plans on making a monthly profit of 24,000 francs CFA that will be used to repay the loan, to build up her working capital, and to take part in events.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying millet

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Terbish

texts.en: Terbish is 50 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in Govi-Altai province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Terbish's two daughters, Narantsetseg and Davaadorj, ages 21 and 19 respectively, are university students. During the day, Terbish operates consumer goods and clothing trading and iron products manufacturing businesses in his town. He sells his products at a local market and his business is well known. Terbish has been operating the consumer goods and clothing trading business since 1998, and has been operating his transportation business with his own truck since 1995. During the winter, Terbish transports coal, and during that time his wife sells their products at a local market. Terbish's whole family supports his business, and the general family atmosphere is very good. Furthermore, Terbish is a talented person who manufactures iron household goods and sells them to his customers from his shipping container at a local market.  His business and family are  very important to him and he and his family work hard for a better quality of life. But the most important thing for him is being able to provide a good education for his children. He is requesting a 2,500,000-tugrug loan to purchase more inventory for his consumer and clothing trading business and to purchase necessary materials to manufacture iron products to sell to his many customers.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Kilipitige

texts.en:
L. is a 57-year-old married woman living in the town of Akurassa in southern Sri Lanka.  She lives with her husband and nine children.
She has a tea cultivation business and her husband is her partner. She has been doing this business for two years so she has lots of experience in tea cultivation.  She knows all the symptoms of infection of tea plants as a result of her experience.  

L. has asked for a 20,000-LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to further develop her tea plants.

L. is honest and careful in her agriculture business. She hopes to provide a nutritious diet to her family through the additional income her business generates.  

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To expand her tea cultivation

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase groceries and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase groceries to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase fairly used clothes to sell

loans.name: Tsedenjargal

texts.en: Tsedenjargal is 45 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, on a plot of land with a yard, which belongs to his aunt. Tsedenjargal manufactures men's suits and coats and his wife, Davaasuren sells them at Narantuul, the biggest market in Mongolia. In addition, they purchase suits in China and sell them at their counter. They have been planning to purchase a large amount of suits in anticipation for the upcoming university and high school graduations in the spring. Tsedenjargal has been operating his business since 1995 and has steadily expanded his business. Tsedenjargal is a very hardworking person and says, “My oldest daughter is going to graduate from her university soon and I started saving money for her graduation. In addition I would like to provide a good education for my son.” He is requesting a 1,500,000-tugrug loan to purchase more inventory for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Battulga

texts.en: Battulga is 44 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. During the day, Battulga operates a second hand shoe trading business with his wife at a local market. He and his wife, Gerelmaa, sometimes repair shoes before they sell them to their customers if it is necessary. They have been operating their business since 2006, and have expanded it over the last four years. Battulga's oldest son, Bayrjargal, a university student, also helps with his parents business when he has free time. Recently, Battulga has started to sell shoes out of another counter in addition to their old one. As Battulga's sales channels expand, he expects that his business will grow as well. Battulga is an experienced trader and a very hardworking person. He says, “It's the first time that I am receiving service from XacBank. They have quick and convenient service.” He is requesting a 1,800,000-tugrug loan to purchase more inventory to supply his new counter.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Jayaseeli

texts.en:
Jayaseeli is a 55-year-old married woman living in Hikkaduwa along the southern coast of Sri Lanka with her husband and son.  The 2004 tsunami in this region devastated the Hikkaduwa area, and Jayaseeli lost two daughters in the tsunami.  She lost all her possessions as well, including her house.  

Jayaseeli has a spice-making business, which she is very enthusiastic about. Jayaseeli has been managing her business by herself, and she devotes her full efforts to improve it, step by step.  

Jayaseeli has asked for a 50,000-LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to expand her business.  This will be her second loan from BRAC to supply capital for the spice business and she hopes to continue to see success.  She is grateful for BRAC because of the financial support it provides to her.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To develop her spice-making business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Dolgorsuren

texts.en: Dolgorsuren is 47 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, in an apartment. Dolgorsuren operates a spare car parts trading business with one of her daughters at the local Ogoomor market. She sells all type of spare parts, but specializes in parts for Korean cars, for which there is high demand in Mongolia. Dolgorsuren sells her products from one shipping container and her daughter Tuyatsetseg sells from another shipping container. Her daily sales revenue is 50,000 – 80,000 tugrugs (~ 35 – 60 USD), and her daily profit is 10,000 – 20,000 tugrugs (~ 10 USD). Korean spare parts demand is very high, especially during the spring when the number of drivers increases with the end of winter. With her business profit, she has built a house for her family and has been paying tuition fees for her children.  Dolgorsuren is a very hardworking person and says, “My dream is one day to open a large spare parts trading shop". She is requesting a 3,000,000-tugrug loan to purchase more Korean spare parts at wholesale prices and resell them for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase more automobile spare parts

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
N. Moses has subsisted on a produce sales business for four years. At the young age of 24 years, he is a fledgling business trendsetter whose example is bound to stand out as a benchmark for other youth in his home area of Kisiita in Mubende district. Many youth in his home area preoccupy themselves in self-destructive activity like drinking. With his hard work, he has managed to take firm root and in a week he apparently makes 50,000 shillings.

With his monthly savings, Moses has managed to diversify his small business. This has, however, not come the easy way as he has had to grapple with many adversities such as the unpredictable weather patterns which, for the most part, mean he has fewer supplies from farmers.

Moses’ dream is to build his own produce stalls to store and keep his surplus goods. With this loan he hopes to implement the aforementioned.

loans.use: To construct extended stalls and a store for selling his produce and for storing his goods

loans.name: Nirodani Madurangi

texts.en:
Nirodani is a 20-year-old married woman living with her husband and three-year-old son.  They live in the town of Hikkaduwa, along the southern coast of Sri Lanka. Her husband is a fisherman and his dream is to purchase a boat.  

So far, they have not received any financial assistance. So Nirodani has requested this loan for her husband's affairs.  They started this business seven years ago and have a good market to sell their fish. Nirodani and her husband are very close and work well together. She is hardworking, active, and a clever woman.  

Nirodani has requested a 40,000-LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to help her husband's fishing business.  Both of them want to create a bright future for their small son.

loans.use: To help purchase a boat

loans.name: Oyun

texts.en:
Oyun is 56 years old and lives with her two daughters in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent.  Currently, Oyun operates a consumer good trading business in her town. She purchases a variety of consumer goods in Ereen, a Chinese border town, and resells them in her rented space for a profit. She has been operating her business since 2006; she has steadily expanded it and has built a stable operation. 

Oyun worked as a pharmacist in a private pharmacy in 2006 and 2007. She is an open-minded and  hardworking person. She says, “I would like to grow my business and improve my family's quality of life.” She is requesting a 500,000 tugrug (~375 USD) loan to increase the working capital of her business.

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Yumjir

texts.en: Yumjir is 38 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. Two of her children, Uuganjargal and Tuvshinsaihan, ages 17 and 9, attend a local secondary school. Her youngest daughter, a four year-old, attends kindergarten. During the day, Yumjir operates a clothing and consumer goods trading business in her town. She purchases products in Ereen, a Chinese border town. Yumjir started her business in 1995, and has expanded her business over the past years. She has been planning to grow her business and product line even further. She is a very hardworking person who has a great business mind.  She is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug (~2195 USD) loan to increase her working capital.

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Sriyani

texts.en:
Sriyani is a married woman living with her husband and two children, ages 10 and 5, in the town of Hikkaduwa on the southern coast of Sri Lanka. 

Her husband is a fisherman and Sriyani has requested this loan for his business. They work together as a team, and have done so for the past 15 years. They are both hardworking and active people.  

Sriyani has requested a 25,000 LKR loan from BRAC to help expand her husband's business affairs.  Both of them want to create a bright future for their children.

loans.use: To expand a fishing business

loans.name: Tsetsgee

texts.en: Tsetsgee is 39 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Her husband operates a taxi service in their town. Currently, Tsetsgee operates a Mongolian fast food restaurant and second-hand shoe-trading business. She has been operating her restaurant since 2007, and has built a stable operation. She also opened a used clothing business in 2008. Over the years, she has been expanding her businesses. Her shoe repair business is seasonal, and does not operate during the winter. Tsetsgee is a very hardworking person and has been working hard to stabilize both her businesses. She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~1475 USD) loan to purchase more inventory for her shoe-trading business.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Mangaljav

texts.en: Mangaljav is 41 years old and lives with his wife and three daughters in Uvs province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Mangaljav operates a transportation business with his own truck. He contracts to bring brick, gravel and soil to construction companies during the spring, summer, and autumn. Mangaljav has been operating his business successfully since 1997 and has a loyal customer base. He would like to purchase a trailer which has a capacity of 10 tons for his truck to transport materials including gravel and soil for the airport construction. Mangaljav built a warehouse and a garage for his truck in 2009. In addition, he created his own auto repair center and has been planning to expand and stabilize his business. Mangaljav is a open-minded person focused on the future. He says, “I started saving money for my three daughters' university tuition fees. I would like to purchase another truck for my business in the future.” He is requesting a 3,500,000 tugrug (~ 2560 USD) loan to purchase a 10-ton trailer for his business.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase empty bottles to sell

loans.name: Biyinzika Kabyuma Group Of Mubende

texts.en:
K. Richard has, over the last five years, been successfully plying his small retail business in Kibyamirizi in Mubende district. With a monthly net profit of 80,000 shillings, this 52-year-old married man has enjoyed the good graces that have come with running this lucrative business. Consequently he has made enormous progress in educating his eight children.

Richard’s first priority after acquiring this loan is to purchase more clothing stock with the sole objective of turning his business into wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more garments and other goods he deals in

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase underwear and jewellery for resale

loans.name: Sanjgerel

texts.en: Sanjgerel is 47 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife, Oyunchimeg, works as a weaver in the Ulaanbaatar carpet factory. Sanjgerel operates a grocery store near his home with the help of his 20-year-old daughter. His grocery store is in a good location and his business is stable. Sanjgerel has been planning to purchase large amounts of products for his store to increase his sales. Sanjgerel is a very hard-working person and says, “I would like to expand my grocery store and to improve its outside design.” He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~ 1465 USD) loan to increase his inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase cooking gas to sell

loans.name: Shirnen

texts.en: Shirnen is a 51-year-old widower who lives with his four children in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Shirnen operates an office supply, photocopy, and computer service business with his oldest son, Anhbaatar, 24 years old. They have been operating this business since 2009. Before that, Shirnen had a taxi service. Originally, he planted and sold vegetables with his wife and whole family until 2007 when his wife unfortunately passed away. Like any responsible father, Shirnen has been working hard to provide a better life for his children. He says, “My family is so important for me and I will work hard to create a bright future for my children.” He is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~  730 USD) loan to purchase more inventory for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more drinks to sell

loans.name: Suleiman

texts.en: Suleimen is 47 years old and lives with his wife and five children in Bayan-Ulgii province, Mongolia. His wife, Janar gets disability payments from the government. His three oldest children attend secondary school and his youngest daughter is in kindergarten. Suleimen operates a transportation business with his minibus. He transports local residents from Bayan-Ulgii province to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia as well as between other provinces. He has successfully operated his business since 2006 and has a loyal customer base. This year he has been transporting his customers between Bayan-Ulgii and Hovd provinces. His minibus has 10 seats and the cost per person is 15,000 tugrugs (~ 10 USD) for a one-way trip. Suleimen's monthly profit is between 240,000 and 300,000 tugrugs (~175  - 220 USD). Suleimen is an experienced driver and a good husband and father to his family. He says, “My family is my treasure. I would like to provide a better life for my family.” He is requesting a 300,000 tugrug (~ 220 USD) loan to purchase two tires for his microbus.

loans.use: To purchase tires for his microbus

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more fresh tomatoes and peppers to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more drinks and items for baking snacks to sell

loans.name: Abisola

texts.en: Abisola is 45 years old and married with four children. She sells soft drinks and is requesting a loan of N30,000 to purchase drinks in large quantity at a reduced cost. She said this will enable her to meet customers' demands while also increasing her own profit. Abisola has been in this business for over eight years ago and is doing well. She lives with her family in Lagos state. She says "thank you."

loans.use: To purchase soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia has a shop where she sells yams. She purchases yams in bulk and sells retail. She gets goods directly from the surrounding village markets and has been in this business since 2000. Lydia is 50 years old, married and has five children. With the profit from her trade, they are able to cloth, feed and take care of their house rent. Lydia is requesting a loan of 100,000 nairas to purchase yams to sell. She says thank you and promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: To purchase yams to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman who is 58 years old with 6 children. Her husband also works to support their home. She lives in Oyo State, Nigeria.

She rears pigs for commercial purposes. She loves this business because it is highly profitable. She has been in this business for 10 years. She is requesting a loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase more feed to boost her business.

She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more feed to boost her business

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more feed to boost her business

loans.use: To purchase drinks to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase tailoring materials to sell

loans.use: To purchase more poultry feed

loans.name: Femmes Commerçantes N°19 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement  Femmes Commerçantes (F.C) comme son nom l’indique est un réseau de femmes qui s’activent  dans le commerce.  Il est basé à Grand Thiès et il a été créé depuis 1992 par Madame Maty Niakh l’actuel président du réseau. Cette présidente a eu cette idée  à l’issue d’une formation qu’elle avait bénéficiée  de l’ONG OXFAM à Thiès. Elle connait, ainsi, bien la gestion de groupe, entreprenariat …etc.  Les membres du réseau sont extrêmement dévoués et se rencontrent une fois par mois. Ainsi, après des frais d’adhésion au groupement, chaque membre est tenu de cotiser mensuellement 200 FCFA pour une caisse de solidarité.
Souhaitant se financer, elles décidèrent  d’adhérer à  U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que,  leur réseau se voit scinder en 19 sous groupes de 5 personnes  pour un meilleur profit des financements. Elles sollicitent pour une deuxième fois un prêt de 100 000 FCFA par membre,  soit 500 000 FCFA par sous groupe afin de développer leurs diverses activités.
Cependant, les règlements sont versés à la présidente assistée par la trésorière du groupe, Madame Coumba Seck, pendant leurs réunions mensuelles et ces deux se chargent à leur tour de rembourser U-IMCEC. Ce réseau qui, dit la présidente, n’a qu’un seul et noble objectif : combattre la pauvreté dans les ménages. Actuellement, le réseau compte 19 sous groupes avec chacun une présidente et une trésorière.
Les Femmes Commerçantes N°19 sont dirigées par Madame Coumba G.. Agée de 56 ans, Madame Coumba G. est commerçante de légumes depuis des années au marché Hersent à Thiès. C’est juste après la mort de son mari qu’elle a commencé à s’activer dans le commerce, il y’a 15 ans. Elle est dans ce sous groupe avec :
-Madame Thioro D., la trésorière âgée de 51 ans et qui vend le petit déjeuner chez elle depuis 10 ans
-Madame Astou G. âgée de 30 ans et  vendeuse d’effets de toilettes au marché. En effet, elle les place à ses clients et ces derniers la règlent journalièment
-Madame Nogaye Daffé, elle est âgée de 52 ans et vend des légumes au marché grand Thiès
-et Madame Aminata N. âgée de 53 ans qui vend du couscous, des tissus chez elle et cela depuis plus de 20 ans.

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase hair extensions and hair accessories.

loans.name: Alabi

texts.en: Alabi is a business woman and has a poultry farm where she rears birds to sell. She also has a piggery where she rears pigs for commercial purposes. She loves this business because of the opportunities to interact with her customers. She has been in the poultry business for a long time. She lives in Oyo State, Nigeria. She is married and has four children. She is 39 years old. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more poultry feed to boost her business. She would like to thank all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more feed to boost her business.

loans.name: Las Flores 1,2 Group

texts.en:
Aureliana is the coordinator of her group "Las Flores" (The Flowers), and her story is typical of her group's members and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) generally. Her group is located in the urban slums surrounding Santiago, the Dominican Republic's second-largest city, know for its tobacco production and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and three children.

Aureliana is excited to be taking her first loan and to "work in harmony" with Esperanza. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling a variety of items including women's shoes, assorted clothing, and accessories. She will use the profits to invest in growing her business as well as constructing a small apartment which she would rent out for extra money. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: to buy women's shoes, assorted clothing and accessories

loans.name: Gladys

texts.es:
La señora Gladys L. vive en casa de sus padres en la zona de Pasankeri de la Ciudad de La Paz, con su esposo, el señor Rogelio Conde y sus tres hijos. La señora Gladys es empleada en una carnicería y su esposo trabaja en una mina que se encuentra en el departamento de La Paz.
El crédito solicitado es para la refacción de una habitación ya que sus hijos crecen y necesitan espacio.
Esta es la séptima ocasión que solicita un préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado lo califica favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Gladys L. lives in her parents’ house in the Pasankeri region of the city of La Paz. She lives with her husband, Rogelio Conde, and their three children. Gladys works in a butcher shop. Her husband works in a mine that is located in the La Paz department. The requested loan is to fix up a room because her children are growing and need space. This is the seventh time she has asked for a loan. The completed socioeconomic analysis qualifies her for a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cost of fixing up a room for her childrenn

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase used clothes to sell

loans.name: Celia Esperanza

texts.es: Celia Esperanza tiene 72 años de edad, Doña Celia tiene 4 hijos y todos trabajan. Su actividad económica es la venta de ropa, golosinas y plásticos. Hace más de 6 años que se dedica a este negocio ella comercializa los productos de manera ambulante, ya que siempre le ha gustado trabajar y ser una mujer muy independiente. Ella solicita este financiamiento  para capital de trabajo para la compra de ropa en general y compra de bolsas. El gran deseo que tiene es proporcionarle mejoras a su vivienda.
texts.en:
Celia Esperanza is 72 years old. Celia has four children, and they all work. She sells clothes, sweets, and plastic products. She has been in this business for over six years. She is a street vendor. She has always liked working and being a very independent woman. She is asking for this loan to buy general clothes and bags. Her big wish is to make some home improvements.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Work capital

loans.name: Femmes Commerçantes N°15 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement  Femmes Commerçantes (F.C) comme son nom l’indique est un réseau de femmes qui s’activent  dans le commerce.  Il est basé à Grand Thiès et il a été créé depuis 1992 par Madame Maty Niakh l’actuel président du réseau. Cette présidente a eu cette idée  à l’issue d’une formation qu’elle avait bénéficiée  de l’ONG OXFAM à Thiès. Elle connait, ainsi, bien la gestion de groupe, entreprenariat …etc.  Les membres du réseau sont extrêmement dévoués et se rencontrent une fois par mois. Ainsi, après des frais d’adhésion au groupement, chaque membre est tenu de cotiser mensuellement 200 FCFA pour une caisse de solidarité.
Souhaitant se financer, elles décidèrent  d’adhérer à  U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que,  leur réseau se voit scinder en 19 sous groupes de 5 personnes  pour un meilleur profit des financements. Elles sollicitent pour une deuxième fois un prêt de 100 000 FCFA par membre,  soit 500 000 FCFA par sous groupe afin de développer leurs diverses activités.
Cependant, les règlements sont versés à la présidente assistée par la trésorière du groupe, Madame Coumba Seck, pendant leurs réunions mensuelles et ces deux se chargent à leur tour de rembourser U-IMCEC. Ce réseau qui, dit la présidente, n’a qu’un seul et noble objectif : combattre la pauvreté dans les ménages. Actuellement, le réseau compte 19 sous groupes avec chacun une présidente et une trésorière.
Les Femmes Commerçantes N°15 ont pour présidente Madame Ndèye Coumba Wolette D. et trésorière Madame Mariama N.. En effet, Madame Ndèye Coumba Wolette  D. mère de 4 enfants est âgée de 32 ans. Elle est dans le commerce de divers légumes, de poissons séchés et de l’huile de palme au marché grand Thiès depuis 4 ans. Cependant la trésorière s’active dans la vente de légumes et poissons fumés  ainsi que Mesdames Astou Sidibé et Aïcha T.. Quant la dernière du sous groupe Madame NoG. G., elle est dans le commerce de salade et divers légumes tout près de l’hôpital régional de Thiès.
texts.en:
The Femmes Commerçantes (F.C.) group, as its name indicates, is a network of women who are involved in business. It’s based in Grand Thiès and was created in 1992 by Mrs. Maty Niakh, the current president of the network. She had the idea to form this network after receiving training from the NGO OXFAM in Thiès. As a result, she is in charge of the group’s management, entrepreneurship, etc. The members of the network are extremely devoted and meet once a month. In addition to membership fees, each member is expected to contribute 200 FCFA monthly to a solidarity fund. Wishing to finance their efforts, they have decided to join U-IMCEC. As a result, their network split into 19 group of 5 people each in order to maximize profits. They are requesting a second loan for 100,000 FCFA per member, or 500,000 FCFA per group, to develop their various activities. However, contributions are paid out to the president, who is assisted by the group’s treasurer, Mrs. Coumba Seck, during their monthly meetings and these two are in charge of reimbursing U-IMCEC. According to their president, this network has only a single and noble goal: fighting poverty among households. Currently, the network consists of 19 groups, each with its own president and treasurer. The president of the Femmes Commerçantes N°15 is Mrs. Ndèye Coumba Wolette D. and the treasurer is Mrs. Mariama N.. Mrs. Ndèye Coumba Wolette D. is a 32-year-old mother of 4. She has been selling various legumes, dried fish, and palm oil at the marketplace in Thiès for four years. Mrs. Mariama N., as well as Mrs. Astou Sidibé and Aïcha T., sell legumes and smoked fish. As for the final member of the group, Mrs. NoG. G., she sells lettuce and various legumes near the Thiès regional hospital.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase items for their business

loans.name: Mujeres Hacia El Progreso Group

texts.en:
Maria is the coordinator of her group, Mujeres Hacia el Progreso (Women Toward Progress), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally, many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti. Her group is located in the urban slums surrounding Santiago, the Dominican Republic's second largest city. Santiago's economy is based around agriculture, and running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. Maria makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband.

Maria is excited to be taking out her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her clothes-selling business by purchasing blouses, underwear, and pants in the main markets and then selling them at a profit in her community. She will use the profits to invest in her goal of owning a vehicle, which will help her continue to expand her business as well as to make her life easier. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy underwear, blouses, and pants to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Rolando

texts.es:
El señor Rolando C. vive en su vivienda propia en la zona de Tacagua, en la ciudad de La Paz.
El señor Rolando trabaja como chofer de transporte publico, ingresos con los que se mantiene.
El préstamo será destinado a la construcción de un garaje en su casa para el vehiculo con el que trabaja, pues actualmente tiene que alquilar uno y eso disminuye sus ingresos mensuales.
Esta es la segunda vez que solicita préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado lo califica favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Rolando C. lives in his own house in the Tacagua region of the city of La Paz. Rolando works as a driver in public transportation. This income supports him. The loan is to build a garage at his house. The garage is for the vehicle he uses to work. He currently has to rent a garage, and this decreases his monthly income. This is the second time he has asked for a loan. The completed socioeconomic evaluation qualifies him for the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a garage at his house to protect the vehicle he uses to provide public transportation.  This will save the rent he now pays.

loans.name: Kyabyakwaga Tukore Of  Kyenjojo District Group

texts.en:
In a certain small Kyenjojo town called Kyabyakwaga is a flourishingly retail shop operated by a 39-year-old go-getter businesswoman who goes by the name of T. Edisa. This stickler for hard work, and also the mother of four, has basked in the checkered career graces of her business for the last eleven years. With this experience behind her, she has managed to subdue most of the uncertain adversities that have threatened to play havoc with her retail business.

In a month Edisa’s business generates her 25,000 shillings. This, to all intents and purposes, is a low figure. What has played into her hands as she operates her business has been her exceptional customer relationship skills. As it is now, she is taking a long view with the aim of maximizing her small profits. She figures this loan will come in significantly handy in helping her buy more stock.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for her retail shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more tailoring material and underwear to sell

loans.name: Fatimata

texts.fr: Madame Fatimata S. née en 1960 est mariée et mère de 10 enfants dont le plus âgé compte 30 ans. Elle s’active dans le commerce depuis 14 ans. Elle vend, en effet, des tissus, parfums, encens et  des pagnes tissés (comme ceux sur la photo) par son mari.  Elle tient le goût du commerce de sa famille composée de grands commerçants. Ce qui l’intéresse le plus de son commerce c’est le coté relationnel qu’elle crée. Ainsi, pour la confection de pagnes, elle sollicite un prêt de 200 000 FCFA pour l’achat de tissus, de fils et d’accessoires nécessaires.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatimata S., born in 1960, is married and the mother of 10 children, the oldest of whom is 30 years old. She has been running a business for 14 years. She sells fabrics, perfumes, incense and “pagnes” (traditional fabrics for wrap clothing), like the ones on the photo, produced by her husband. She has a knack for this trade as she comes from a family known in the commerce. What particularly attracts her to this business is the relationships she is able to build. Thus, in order to produce “pagnes”, she is seeking a loan of 200,000 West African Francs, to purchase cloth, threads and necessary accessories.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing raw materials for the production of traditional 'pagnes" fabric

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase tailoring material to sell

loans.name: Justina Emperatriz

texts.es: Justina Emperatriz tiene mucho tiempo de trabajar con Fundación León 2000, por lo que siempre le ha gustado mejorar su negocio por medio de los financiamientos. Ella tiene 67 años, tiene la actividad económica de una pulpería. Hace más de 5 años que se dedica a este negocio ya que dio inicio con muy pocos productos, pero por medio de los financiamientos ha logrado mejorar cada día su negocio. Sueña con incrementar su negocio y además proporcionar el pan de cada día a su familia. El financiamiento que solicita es para la compra de materia prima así podrá una amplia variedad de productos a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Justina Emperatriz has worked with Funcación León 2000 for a long time. She has always liked improving her business with the loans. She is 67 years old. She has a mini-market. She has been in this business for over five years. She started with very few products, but she has been able to improve her business everyday with the loans. She dreams of expanding her business and providing her family with their daily bread. The loan she is requesting is to buy raw material to be able to have a greater variety of products for her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Maty

texts.fr:
Madame Maty S. est un agent de santé communautaire au niveau de l’ONG Child Fund depuis 2003.  Couturière de métier, Madame S. est devenue agent de santé après avoir réussie aux tests de sélection organisés à cet effet. Elle fait partie à présent des principales motivatrices communautaire de l’ONG au niveau de ses bases qui se trouvent à Thiès.
A présent, Madame S. Maty avait entamé des travaux de construction d’un bâtiment pour sa chère maman. Ainsi  pour la finition des travaux à savoir le dallage et autre, elle sollicite un prêt de 300 000 FCFA  afin de loger dans les plus brefs délais sa maman dans un bâtiment neuf et de la rendre plaisir.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maty S. is a public health agent with the Child Fund NGO since 2003. She is a seamstress by trade, and has become a public health agent after successfully passing qualifying tests. She now belongs to the main group of NGO community organizers based in Thiès. At present, Mrs. Maty S. has launched theconstruction of a house for her beloved mother. In order to have masonry and other skilled work completed, Mrs. S. is seeking a loan of 300,000 West African Francs so that her mother would be able to move into a new house and enjoy it as soon as possible.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Finishing the construction of a house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase handbags to sell

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr: Madame Fatoumata D. sollicite un prêt de 50 000 FCFA pour réapprovisionner sa boutique sise au niveau de son quartier Randoulène Nord à Thiès. Elle est âgée de 36 ans et mariée mère de 2 ans dont le plus âgé compte 7 années. C’est en 2002 qu’elle a ouvert la boutique avec l’aide de son mari qui l’a financé au départ. Elle est membre de U-IMCEC depuis 2008 et elle est à sa 1ère demande de prêt.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatoumata D. is seeking a loan of 50,000 FCFA to restock her shop located in the Randoulène Nord neighborhood in Thiès. She is 36 years old and a married mother of two, the oldest of which is 7. In 2002, she opened her shop with the help of her husband, who financed the opening. She has been a member of the U-IMCEC since 2008, and this is her first loan application.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to stock up on products for her little shop

loans.name: Sekinat

texts.en: Sekinat is a hardworking and honest woman. She sells medicine at retail prices to make a living. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger. She is happily married, 38 years old and has two children. Her husband also works to support their home. She is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more medicine to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more cassava

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more bags of wheat to sell

loans.name: Seynabou

texts.fr: Employée au niveau de la cuisine de l’hôpital régional de Thiès depuis 1996, Madame Seynabou M. s’active parallèlement dans le commerce. D’ailleurs c’est une activité qu’elle a embrassé depuis son enfance sous l’influence de ses parents qui s’activaient également dans le commerce. Après avoir réglée un prêt de façon rationnelle et sans aucuns retards, là voilà pour une deuxième fois demandée un autre crédit de 500 000 FCFA pour s’approvisionner en marchandises (mil, poissons fumés, poissons séchés ……) destinées à la vente. Les résultats tirés de l’ancien prêt lui ont permis d’épargner dans la mutuelle U-IMCEC et d’acheter des bijoux en or pour dit elle créer de la valeur.
texts.en:
Employed in the kitchen of the regional hospital in Thiès since 1996, Mrs. Seynabou M. also sells things. It is something she has embraced since her childhood under the influence of her parents who also sold things. After having repaid a loan with no problems or late payments, she is seeking another loan of 500,000 FCFA to stock up on products (millet, smoked fish, dried fish,…) to sell. The profits she made from the first loan allowed her to save in U-IMCEC and to buy gold jewelry which will go up in value.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to stock up on products

loans.name: Martina

texts.es: Martina  es una mujer muy responsable, que ha demostrado ser una excelente cliente con Fundación, por lo que no es la primera vez que realiza financiamientos. Ella se dedica a ofrecer los servicios de costura, hace mas de de 11 años que se dedica a esta actividad por lo que siempre le ha gustado mantener a sus hijos ya que ha demostrado que puede salir adelante a pesar de ser una madre soltera, ella inicio este negocio aplicando sus conocimientos y elaborando prendas de vestir que le encargaban. Ella se levanta muy temprano para elaborar los encargos que pendientes de sus clientes, pues gana mucha fama por la responsabilidad de la entrega de las prendas de vestir. Ella solicita este préstamo para la compra de tela, hilo, botones, encajes, agujas y tijeras. Sueña con obtener un taller muy grande en donde fuentes de empleo.
texts.en:
Martina is a very responsible woman, and she has shown that she is an excellent client with Fundación. This is not her first time with a loan. She offers seamstress services. She has been doing this for over 11 years. She has always liked supporting her children. She has shown that she can get ahead in spite of being a single mother. She started her business by applying her knowledge and making articles of clothing that were ordered. She gets up very early to make her customers’ pending orders. She has become well know because of how responsible she is about delivering the clothing. She is asking for this loan to buy fabric, thread, buttons, lace, needles, and scissors. She dreams of having a very large shop where she can be a source of employment.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en: Paulina is a hardworking and honest woman. She sells bags of poultry feed at retail prices to make a living. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger. She is 45 years old and happily married with four children. Her children are doing well at school and this gives her joy as a mother. Her husband also works to support their home. She is requesting a loan of 80,000 nairas to purchase more bags of poultry feed to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of poultry feed to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Leah

texts.en: Leah is a hard-working and honest woman. She sells medicines and groceries at retail prices to make a living. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger. She hopes to own a big pharmacy stall in the future. She is 41 years old and happily married, with 3 children. Her husband also works to support their home. She is requesting a loan amount of 80,000 NGN to purchase more medicines to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Ntonwa Bakyara Group Of Kyenjojo

texts.en:
On the face of it, B. Deus seems a hard-grinding businessman. The 39-year-old married father of seven school-going kids sweats his guts out selling produce in a small rural town called Ntonwa in Kyenjojo district. He has been doing this for the last three years.

In a month Deus makes close to 30,000 shillings. This is quite modest by any standards. As such he requires a loan that will help him buy more food supplies for his business.

loans.use: To buy additional produce like beans maize and coffee

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more sachet water and drinks to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: The Women´s Bank Of United Hands (Banco Mujer Manos Unidas) Group

texts.en: The name of this group is Banco Mujer Manos Unidas which translates as "The Women´s Bank of United Hands". The nine women members live in the rural area of Pococí, Limón, located near the Caribbean coast of Costa Rica. Opportunities for employment are scarce in Pococí; many families rely on the production of subsistence crops and raising livestock in order to maintain their standard of living. The members of this group are involved in various productive activities including hen rearing for the production and sale of eggs, chicken rearing in order to produce quality poultry products and pig rearing in order to produce pork products. This loan will be used by each individual member to make necessary investments for the growth of their businesses to increase revenues and for the improvement of the lives of their families. The majority of this loan will be put towards the purchase of livestock and animal feed. Flor E. R. is a 39-year-old mother of four and the elected president of Banco Mujer Manos Unidas. She lives with her husband and three of her children. One of her daughters is studying Business Administration at the National University in Sarapiqui. She has one and a half years left until graduation. On their land, Flor and her family have planted subsistence crops including rice, beans, corn and plantains, among others. At the moment, Flor is raising 20 chickens, one pig to be slaughtered and sold, and 30 hens whose eggs will later be sold. She plans to invest this loan in the purchase of 40 more hens as well as nutrients and vitamins to feed them. Flor will be able to use family-produced corn to feed her chickens, but she will need to buy special vitamins to fight off dangerous parasites which could infect the animals. Her main challenges are coping with the high costs of animal vitamins and the occasional electricity problems at home, due to the fact that Flor and her family live in a rural area, 600 meters from the nearest road. At the moment, Flor is altering her production methods in order to produce 100% organically. This method of production is favourable to Flor because she "wants to provide a higher quality product and [she] is more comfortable eating food when [she] is conscious of the composition of all the nutrients used in its production" (meat products, crops, fertilizers and gas). Her main goal is to increase organic production on her land and to become independently sustainable, meaning she would like to use only home grown products in production. She would also like to install a biodigester (equipment used to harness animal discharge in order to produce gas for cooking). This equipment is sometimes donated to farmers by the Costa Rican government. Flor has known the other members of her group for 8 years. She says that applying for a loan in a group is better because the women can help each other to succeed in their businesses and repay their loans. Zelmira F. plans to use this loan to buy chicks and nutrients to feed them. When the chicks are ready, she will sell them and their eggs to neighbours and acquaintances in the community. Zelmira sells 12 eggs for 1000 colones (roughly $2 US). She mentions the importance of maintaining the good health of her animals in order to ensure a quality end product.

loans.use: For the purchase of livestock and animal feed

loans.use: To purchase noodles in bulk

loans.use: To purchase more building materials to sell

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell
